title: Your job is to deliver code you have proven to work

summary: Your job is to deliver code you have proven to work (6 minute read) A software developer's core responsibility is to deliver code that has been proven to work. The practice of submitting large, untested pull requests is a dereliction of duty that unfairly burdens reviewers. Proving code works involves two essential steps: thorough manual testing to personally verify functionality and demonstrate it, and bundling automated tests that validate the change.

title: One weird trick to manage engineering crises; stakeholders love it
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-19, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.brethorsting.com%2Fblog%2F2025%2F12%2Fone-weird-trick-to-manage-engineering-crises;-stakeholders-love-it%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b3683b962-8d8db0ee-ecf6-49cd-8c9d-af71df50d34e-000000/HILgLXImTKKVHgH_NeCmrMSwtRQTSbg3YVUBIvS9saY=436
summary: One weird trick to manage engineering crises; stakeholders love it (5 minute read) Tactical wins address a specific symptom with a specific fix. These wins matter because they demonstrate traction. Strategic investments don't fix individual problems, but instead eliminate entire classes of problems. The trick is to sequence tactical wins and strategic investments to reinforce each other. Transparency will help stakeholders understand the tradeoffs you are making.

title: NVME is not a hard disk
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-19, Reading time: 14 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.koehntopp.info%2F2021%2F05%2F25%2Fnvme-is-not-a-hard-disk.html%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b3683b962-8d8db0ee-ecf6-49cd-8c9d-af71df50d34e-000000/k-GAdjBEeA8RKELNEQz5vucm9aseZQvqTCnGze_VGYA=436
summary: NVME is not a hard disk (14 minute read) NVMe (nonvolatile memory express) is a storage access and transport protocol for flash and next-generation solid-state drives that delivers high throughput and fast response times for all types of enterprise workloads. NVME over fabric over TCP allows you to make storage available even if it is in the wrong box. Distributed storage may be complicated, but it has a number of very attractive use cases.

title: Coca-Cola Christmas Ad Controversy: Can AI Replace Human Creativity in Marketing?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-19, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.marketergems.com%2Fp%2Fcoca-cola-ai-generated-holiday-campaign-marketing-breakdown%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/0100019b368ce917-6e2b954b-4fb4-4fbc-a763-41d174adb847-000000/UPyx6fQFG4sU8jiUCmqe0O5zNGkfXDwnPHq0xeWS2p0=436
summary: Coca-Cola Christmas Ad Controversy: Can AI Replace Human Creativity in Marketing? Durable data quality comes from disciplined processes and ownership, not a single tool.

summary: US Plans Largest Nuclear Power Program Since the 1970s (6 minute read) The Trump administration launched a partnership in October to build at least $80 billion worth of new, large-scale nuclear reactors. The partnership includes profit-sharing mechanisms that will give the US government some of the upside if the initiative succeeds.

title: Design is more than code

summary: Design is more than code (9 minute read) Design is about finding the right problem, the right intent, and the right vision. The features you design and build today should be considered a step toward that vision. Without the right context and goal, you could be iterating toward a direction that wasn't chosen intentionally. The industry is not very patient, but that doesn't mean you should devalue the why behind your designs in favor of output.

title: Logging sucks
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Reading time: 12 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Floggingsucks.com%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019b45f3b9fb-9e07cbe1-ecac-48c8-bf0f-2f926a3c8f15-000000/qlMUwfE-dc8Zv0BwvlPA9rYh7lKNd85B_g6LvhEahVI=436
summary: Logging sucks (12 minute read) Traditional logs are noisy, low-context, and optimized for writing, not for answering real debugging questions in distributed systems. The fix is wide events (canonical log lines): emit one high-cardinality, high-dimensional, context-rich event per request (with tail sampling). This turns debugging from grep-based archaeology into fast, analytical queries.

summary: Performance Hints (40 minute read) Jeff Dean and Sanjay Ghemawat, some of Google's most important engineers for over 25 years, wrote a guide on optimizing software performance. Performance needs to be considered early in critical code paths instead of solely relying on post-development profiling for optimization. The guide also covers algorithmic improvements, efficient memory representation, reducing allocations, avoiding unnecessary work, and using parallelization.

title: Introducing CSS Grid Lanes
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Reading time: 10 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwebkit.org%2Fblog%2F17660%2Fintroducing-css-grid-lanes%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b45f7df31-8b7da767-1b18-4f2f-8328-54fa1d6040d8-000000/Nd7hTpoj2bK8FBbji1kE__KPgMpoDfdjKp7t8OxyARo=436
summary: Introducing CSS Grid Lanes (10 minute read) CSS Grid Lanes is a new web standard to natively create flexible, dynamic masonry-style layouts on the web without JavaScript. This feature uses `display: grid-lanes` along with existing CSS Grid properties like `grid-template-columns` or `grid-template-rows` to define the layout's structure. It supports advanced capabilities such as variable lane sizes, item spanning, explicit placement, and introduces a "tolerance" property for fine-tuning item pa...

title: Code review as human alignment, in the era of LLMs
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.ezyang.com%2F2025%2F12%2Fcode-review-as-human-alignment-in-the-era-of-llms%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b45f7df31-8b7da767-1b18-4f2f-8328-54fa1d6040d8-000000/sYijgeSV1JrxhAPTglf8QbQR15teHkeL94DoEr341wI=436
summary: Code review as human alignment, in the era of LLMs (3 minute read) Code review within teams should change to be primarily a human alignment mechanism. Large language models have no memory and have to rediscover everything in the system from first principles every time they are run. Humans can collectively maintain a shared vision of what the system should do. Code review should reconfigure itself around this purpose.

title: More databases should be single-threaded
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.konsti.xyz%2Fmore-databases-should-be-single-threaded%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b45f7df31-8b7da767-1b18-4f2f-8328-54fa1d6040d8-000000/6vh1gfuUIQL-TVtDYEnyjPxiDHjm-dP5Jahon5yNmyI=436
summary: More databases should be single-threaded (8 minute read) From a DX perspective, every transaction within a shard would always be serializable and never needs to be retried, making it much easier to think about. A single-threaded database would be fully horizontally scalable and have extremely high per-thread throughput, as it wouldn't need to sync with other threads. It would be a much more predictable system. While more restrictive, there would be no more hidden race conditions.

title: TRON
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Ffastserial%2Flite3%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b45f7df31-8b7da767-1b18-4f2f-8328-54fa1d6040d8-000000/euctDBrXc_jeT3IxTUGn1wBovu3O714tl58mitU-rzc=436
summary: TRON (GitHub Repo) Lite³ (TRON) is a zero-copy, schemaless binary serialization format that organizes data as a B-tree within a single contiguous buffer. This design allows for direct, O(log n) access and mutation of data fields without traditional parsing or serialization steps. It supports conversion to/from JSON, but is much more performant.

title: 2025 LLM Year in Review
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fkarpathy.bearblog.dev%2Fyear-in-review-2025%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b45f7df31-8b7da767-1b18-4f2f-8328-54fa1d6040d8-000000/aRRmLzQ7wZryndXcvEEe9_kRAaTkKEVR57XeCl1c380=436
summary: 2025 LLM Year in Review (9 minute read) 2025 was an eventful year for LLMs, with paradigm shifts that redefined the field. Reinforcement Learning from Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) came up as a new training stage, allowing LLMs to develop reasoning strategies and driving much of the year's capability progress. The year also saw the rise of new application layers, local AI agents like Claude Code, "vibe coding" that democratized programming, and early hints of a visual LLM GUI.

The project archives a "long tail" of less popular music and makes the entire archive openly mirrorable.

title: Google's AI Uses Schema?

summary: Google's AI Uses Schema? (2 minute read) Google Gemini may use structured data or hidden page content to ground AI search answers, but this has not been proven yet. Clear proof of Gemini's scheme use requires pages where schema text and page text differ, so experts can see what it uses.

title: New UEFI Flaw Enables Pre-Boot Attacks From Gigabyte, MSI, ASUS, ASRock
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.bleepingcomputer.com%2Fnews%2Fsecurity%2Fnew-uefi-flaw-enables-pre-boot-attacks-on-motherboards-from-gigabyte-msi-asus-asrock%2F%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/0100019b4663f016-1d65b79a-f1bc-46cc-9f58-e82be1047dbf-000000/oGFTwzrkD6w-lGibIFrsqf3-pER_thGyb9HivhTrZNE=436
summary: New UEFI Flaw Enables Pre-Boot Attacks From Gigabyte, MSI, ASUS, ASRock (2 minute read) Researchers from Riot Games discovered a UEFI flaw that could allow for Direct Memory Access (DMA) capable devices to load before the operating system. DMA allows for PCIe devices to read and write RAM without going through the CPU and relies upon IOMMU for protection. A physically present attacker would need to attach a rogue PCIe device before boot to exploit this vulnerability.

title: Understanding AI Benchmarks
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Reading time: 25 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.sshh.io%2Fp%2Funderstanding-ai-benchmarks%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b466e0c2d-a5ea44ed-9401-4a24-8e01-f00a8e2beee4-000000/XWH9R3mHfkmCxN0qCweiH8tz2_0j43dfIV_j3GIfIvw=436
summary: Understanding AI Benchmarks (25 minute read) Benchmarks are the most widely misunderstood part of the AI ecosystem. The narrative keeps implying a universal increase in intelligence, but the numbers can be misleading. To navigate this noise, look at the aggregate, look at the relative, and verify with your own tasks. The only benchmark that matters at the end of the day is your own workload.

It can run anywhere a browser can run.

summary: How to game the METR plot (9 minute read) METR topics are public, making it easy to game METR horizon length measurements for a frontier lab. title: Your Laptop Isn't Ready for LLMs. That's About to Change
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-23, Reading time: 10 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fspectrum.ieee.org%2Fai-models-locally%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019b4af34c38-387c2a2b-1bd9-404a-ab9b-37772c7f8978-000000/yPuz__aNZgkap3bCSf8TUs_Vf2gzJtGSWFfvUy8fMoI=437
summary: Your Laptop Isn't Ready for LLMs. That's About to Change (10 minute read) Laptop designs need to be upgraded to make running AI models locally possible. The average laptop is underpowered for large language models. The most obvious way to boost a PC's AI performance is to place a powerful NPU alongside the CPU. Another upgrade required for PCs to run AI models is a unified memory architecture that provides all system resources to the same pool of memory over a fast, interconnected memory bus.

title: Training the Idea Muscle
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-23, Reading time: 13 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fsfalexandria.com%2Fposts%2Frileys-ideas%2F%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019b4af34c38-387c2a2b-1bd9-404a-ab9b-37772c7f8978-000000/am_RuuNDS5pfIQ3mVfgzz8aSuJZ81AjF98EEXxFzqjI=437
summary: Training the Idea Muscle (13 minute read) Riley Walz is known for his many creative projects. He always has over 50 ideas in his backlog at any point, so there's always something for him to do. Walz only works on ideas he thinks are fun. If you reject your own ideas, the part of the brain that comes up with ideas is going to stop. Making your ideas a reality again and again is the only way to generate better ones over time. There's no such thing as an impossible idea.

title: Logging Sucks
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-23, Reading time: 18 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Floggingsucks.com%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b4b1c6d21-17968b35-54cd-4308-975c-6c0bcf53281a-000000/kmpmpStG8rY7uCcVU0PFPEF722km_ziAionr4E4QOLs=437
summary: Logging Sucks (18 minute read) Traditional logging is inadequate for modern, distributed systems, usually providing little useful context for debugging issues. A shift to "wide events" or canonical log lines, which are single, comprehensive log entries emitted per request per service, may solve this problem. These events are rich in high-cardinality and high-dimensionality data, allowing for powerful queries and analytics instead of string searches.

title: Scaling LLMs to larger codebases
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-23, Reading time: 12 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.kierangill.xyz%2Foversight-and-guidance%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b4b1c6d21-17968b35-54cd-4308-975c-6c0bcf53281a-000000/Nzko7PXp3_d1hdhLqCsE7M0TfAme9p2uVAKD2f9Id84=437
summary: Scaling LLMs to larger codebases (12 minute read) Scaling LLMs within large codebases requires investments in both guidance and oversight. Guidance focuses on providing LLMs with high-quality context, such as prompt libraries and well-structured, modular codebases, to allow for efficient "one-shot" code generation without needing a lot of rework. Oversight refers to human engineers who validate LLM choices, making sure of architectural integrity and aligned solutions.

title: How to Do a Social Media Competitor Analysis
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-23, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2Fagtelw/1/0100019b4b2322ba-d4c82aec-b351-47f9-b138-d2955f67f4fb-000000/_bB4bKbw5EZX2U48V1eTNeXT-K0eufQCz6tCdIC07TY=437

summary: Here's why Google Ads fail quietly (1 minute read) Google Ads performance often fails quietly due to over-segmentation. title: Introducing Manus Design View
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-23, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmanus.im%2Fblog%2Fmanus-design-view%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b4b924458-2d845cd0-5afb-4732-ab94-fb15a2c8e6ca-000000/VJGYN_mmjbsHGe5xZNQGImlgz_XY9OGEG9PxgUXUaek=436
summary: Introducing Manus Design View (3 minute read) Manus Design View is an extension of the Manus agent for seamless AI design workflows. It enables designers to generate concepts with simple prompts, make precise edits using the Mark Tool, and change text easily. The Manus mobile app allows design edits on-the-go with either text or voice input. It is available to all users today.
